title: Adult Income using Naive Bayes Classifier
description: You are provided with the Adult Income dataset (adult.csv), which contains demographic and employment-related information about individuals.

parts.description:
Your task is to develop a Naive Bayes Classifier to predict whether a person’s income exceeds $50,000 per year based on various attributes such as age, education, occupation, hours worked per week, and more.
Predict the Precision value using the Naïve Bayes Classifier for the Adult Income Dataset.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset using pandas and handle any missing values by dropping the corresponding rows.
2.	Encode all categorical features using LabelEncoder from sklearn.preprocessing.
3.	Separate the dataset into input features (X) and the target column (income).
4.	Split the dataset into training (70%) and testing (30%) sets using train_test_split() with random_state = 42.
5.	Train a Gaussian Naive Bayes (GaussianNB) model from sklearn.naive_bayes on the training data.
6.	Predict the income classes on the test dataset.
7.	Evaluate the model performance using the following metrics (with weighted averages):
•	Precision
•	Recall
•	F1-Score
8.	Display the Precision value rounded to 4 decimal places.

Predict the Classification Report using the Decision Tree Classifier for the Adult Income Dataset.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset using pandas and handle any missing values by dropping the corresponding rows.
2.	Encode all categorical features using LabelEncoder from sklearn.preprocessing.
3.	Separate the dataset into input features (X) and the target column (income).
4.	Split the dataset into training (70%) and testing (30%) sets using train_test_split() with random_state = 42.
5.	Train a DecisionTreeClassifier model from sklearn.tree on the training data with max_depth=10.
6.	Predict the income classes on the test dataset.
7.	Evaluate the model performance using the following metrics (with weighted averages):
     •	Precision
     •	Recall
     •	F1-Score
8.	Display the Classification Report using classification_report() from sklearn.metrics.
9.	Print the Classification Report saved in the 'classification.csv' file.

title: Adult Income to predict recall and confusion matrix
description: You are provided with the Adult Income dataset (adult.csv), which contains demographic and employment-related information about individuals.

parts.description:
Your task is to develop a Naive Bayes Classifier to predict whether a person’s income exceeds $50,000 per year based on various attributes such as age, education, occupation, hours worked per week, and more.

Predict the Recall value using the Naïve Bayes Classifier for the Adult Income Dataset.

Constraints:

1. Load the dataset using pandas and handle any missing values by dropping the corresponding rows.
2.  Encode all categorical features using LabelEncoder from sklearn.preprocessing.
3.  Separate the dataset into input features (X) and the target column (income).
4. Split the dataset into training (70%) and testing (30%) sets using train_test_split() with random_state = 42.
5. Train a Gaussian Naive Bayes (GaussianNB) model from sklearn.naive_bayes on the training data.
6.  Predict the income classes on the test dataset.
7. Evaluate the model performance using the following metrics (with weighted averages):
·       Precision
·       Recall
·       F1-Score
8. Display the Recall value rounded to 4 decimal places.

Predict the Confusion Matrix using the Decision Tree Classifier for the Adult Income Dataset.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset using pandas and handle any missing values by dropping the corresponding rows.
2.	Encode all categorical features using LabelEncoder from sklearn.preprocessing.
3.	Separate the dataset into input features (X) and the target column (income).
4.	Split the dataset into training (70%) and testing (30%) sets using train_test_split() with random_state = 42.
5.	Train a DecisionTreeClassifier model from sklearn.tree on the training data with max_depth=10.
6.	Predict the income classes on the test dataset.
7.	Display the Confusion Matrix using confusion_matrix() from sklearn.metrics. [index= 'Actual_0' and 'Actual_1'], columns= 'Pred_0' and 'Pred_1']

title: Bank Marketing using Random Forest to print confusion matrix
description: You are provided with a dataset named bank.csv, which contains customer information related to a bank’s marketing campaign.

parts.description:
Build a Random Forest Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split data into 70% train and 30% test (random_state=42).
4.	Train a RandomForestClassifier with n_estimators=100, max_depth=None, and random_state=42.
5. Predict the confusion matrix using the confusion_matrix() from sklearn.metrics. [index= 'Actual_No' and 'Actual_Yes'], columns= 'Pred_No' and 'Pred_Yes']
6. Save the file in the form of rf_confusion_matrix.csv.

Your task is to apply a Decision Tree Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit (deposit column).

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split data into 70% train and 30% test (random_state=42).
4.	Train a DecisionTreeClassifier with max_depth = 10 and random_state = 42.
5.	Evaluate performance and print the precision value rounded to 4 decimals.

title: Bank Marketing using Decision Tree Classifier to print F1-Score
description: You are provided with a dataset named bank.csv, which contains customer information related to a bank’s marketing campaign.

parts.description:
Your task is to apply a Decision Tree Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit (deposit column).

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split data into 70% train and 30% test (random_state=42).
4.	Train a DecisionTreeClassifier with max_depth = 10 and random_state = 42.
5.	Evaluate performance and print the F1-Score value rounded to 4 decimals, Use weighted average for multi-class problems.

Build a SVM Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split the data into 70% train and 30% test.
4.	Train an SVM model(random_state=42).
5.	Evaluate the performance and print the Recall value rounded to 4 decimals, Use weighted average for multi-class problems.

title: Bank Marketing using Random Forest classifier to print the model accuracy
description: You are provided with a dataset named bank.csv, which contains customer information related to a bank’s marketing campaign.

parts.description:
Build a Random Forest Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split data into 70% train and 30% test (random_state=42).
4.	Train a RandomForestClassifier with n_estimators=100, max_depth=None, and random_state=42.
5.	Print the Random Forest Model Accuracy using y_test with 4 decimal values.[Sample output: Random Forest Model Accuracy: x.xxxx]

Build a SVM Classifier to predict whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit.

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Encode categorical columns using LabelEncoder.
3.	Split the data into 70% train and 30% test.
4.	Train an SVM model(random_state=42).
5.	Evaluate the performance using test data(y_test) and print the Precision value rounded to 4 decimals, Use weighted average for multi-class problems.

title: Wine Quality Prediction using Random Forest Classifier to predict the quality category of the wine (good or bad).
description: You are provided with a dataset named WineQT.csv, which contains various physicochemical properties of wines and their corresponding quality scores.

parts.description:
Build a Random Forest Classifier to predict the quality category of the wine (good or bad).

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Convert the quality column into a binary target variable:
•	Assign 1 if quality >= 7 (Good quality wine)
•	Assign 0 if quality < 7 (Bad quality wine).
3.	Split the data into 70% training and 30% testing sets (random_state=42).
4.	Train a RandomForestClassifier with n_estimators=100, max_depth=None, and random_state=42.
5.	Print the Random Forest Model Accuracy on the test data (y_test) with 4 decimal places.
[Sample Output: Random Forest Model Accuracy: x.xxxx]

You are provided with a dataset named WineQT.csv, which contains various physicochemical properties of wines and their corresponding quality scores.
Build a Support Vector Machine (SVM) Classifier to predict the quality category of the wine (good or bad).

Constraints:
1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Convert the quality column into a binary target variable:
•	Assign 1 if quality >= 7 (Good quality wine).
•	Assign 0 if quality < 7 (Bad quality wine).
3.	Standardize all feature values using StandardScaler.
4.	Split the data into 70% training and 30% testing sets (random_state=42).
5.	Train a SVC (Support Vector Classifier) with kernel='rbf', C=1.0, and gamma='scale'.
6.	Print the SVM Model Accuracy on the test data (y_test) with 4 decimal places.
[Sample output: SVM Model Accuracy: x.xxxx]

title: Wine Quality Prediction using Random Forest Classifier to predict the loss value
description: You are provided with a dataset named WineQT.csv, which contains various physicochemical properties of wines and their corresponding quality scores.

parts.description:
Build a Random Forest Classifier to predict the quality category of the wine (good or bad).

Constraints:

1.	Load the dataset and drop missing values.
2.	Convert the quality column into a binary target variable:
•	Assign 1 if quality >= 7 (Good quality wine)
•	Assign 0 if quality < 7 (Bad quality wine).
3.	Split the data into 70% training and 30% testing sets (random_state=42).
4.	Apply feature standardization using StandardScaler.
5.	Train a RandomForestClassifier with:
•	n_estimators=100
•	max_depth=None
•	random_state=42
6.	Use the trained model to predict class probabilities on the test set using predict_proba().
7.	Compute and print the Log Loss between the true labels (y_test) and predicted probabilities (y_pred_proba), rounded to 4 decimal places.[Sample Output: Random Forest Log Loss: x.xxxx]

You are provided with a dataset named WineQT.csv, which contains various physicochemical properties of wines and their corresponding quality scores.
Build a Support Vector Machine (SVM) Classifier to predict the quality category of the wine (good or bad).

Constraints:

1.	Use the WineQT.csv dataset and remove any missing values.
2.	Convert the quality column into a binary target variable where:
•	1 → quality ≥ 7 (good wine)
•	0 → otherwise (average or poor wine)
3.	Split the dataset into 70% training and 30% testing sets using random_state=42.
4.	Apply feature standardization using StandardScaler.
5.	Train an SVM classifier with the following parameters:
•	kernel = 'rbf'
•	C = 1.0
•	gamma = 'scale'
•	probability = True
•	random_state = 42
6.	Compute and display the weighted recall score for model evaluation.
[Sample output: Recall: x.xxxx]
